column16:
Provides for flexibility in the addition of new observation and unit codes (1.2.5.6, Obtaining the Observation Code, 1.2.5.7, Obtaining the Unit Code), which is important for emerging diseases and evolving public health priorities.
Under 1.2.5.10, Generating the PHD Reported Time Stamp Identifier, absolute time is recorded.  Coincident Time Stamp is also collected, may not allow for deriving local time when device out of range, transmission asynchronous. 
Is local device timestamp or time zone also collected? How to ensure we know time relative to patient’s perspective?
Nothing tobacco specific or unique to tobacco use that would raise questions. Any data collected pertaining to tobacco use would be under Questionnaire CDA or captured under Observation.code.coding.code element which is flexible.
column17: Is local device timestamp or time zone also collected? How to ensure we know time relative to patient’s perspective?
column21: Duplicate of comments submitted by Mitra Rocca

column16: Readers not familiar with the reference to 11073 20601 would benefit from qualifying the standard number with IEEE.  (other references in 1.1.2)  1.2 reference is qualified by "PHD"  1.2.2 reference not qualified, etc. Also 1.2.2  (note - in 1.2.3.6, the reference is qualified, confirming that this is an IEEE std reference)  In general throughout the spec, there are references to specifications other than the IG that assume the reader will recognize them.

column14: Another use case is participation in medical research. For example, a medical center associated with a large university is conducting a study on memory impairment interventions in the elderly. The study involves the patients participating in adaptive on-line memory ‘games’. The data is collected in association with a home healthcare service. The use of remote monitoring allows the study to collect a large set of data with minimal impact on the involved patients. The automated approach reduces cost, increases sample size, allows the collection of larger amounts of data from each participant, and the minimal impact is likely to result in longer participation times.

column14: "The Accuracy attribute gives the maximum deviation as an absolute value of the reported measurement from the actual measurement over the entire range of the measurement. The reported accuracy is, thus, static and does not vary over the range of the measurement. It shall be reported if the PHD provides it and it is not corrupted. It is in the units of the measurement itself. This kind of measurement may not make sense to report with some compound measurements, especially in the case of the Compound-Nu-Observed-Value as each element could have different units."
column16: Explain what level of accuracy deems the measurements as useful. Is the PHG going to translate the accuracy into something patient, clinicians, and researchers can understand?
column17: What does the accuracy mean to patients or clinicians? According to the use cases this data is intended to be used by patients, clinicians, or researchers/

column17: Link narrative and profile pages

column16: The profiles in this IG should make use of the "must support" flag. For example, in the PhdBaseObservation profile, Observation.code contains two codings, one for MDC codes at 1..1 and a second for LOINC codes at 0..1. The second coding should use the must support flag so that systems are required to support it even if not populated. I would also suggest reviewing all fields with a 1..1 cardinality to see if some of them would be better represented with 0..1 and must support if there is any possibility that a sender may not have data to populate in that field (or take another approach like adding HL7 nullFlavor codes to the value sets, etc.).
column17: The profiles in this IG should make use of the "must support" flag.

column16: Many of the profiles just list MDC as the terminology, but that is a very broad coding system covering devices, observations, etc. The entirety of MDC is not appropriate for most of the bindings. Please add more guidance in the form of ValueSet resources for things like Observation.component.code.
column17: Add more guidance in the form of ValueSet resources for things like Observation.component.code.

column14: Bluetooth Low Energy devices use an exchange protocol that is not generically extensible. Special implementation code is needed for every health device profile and service. The non-generic extensibility means that PHDs supporting a new Bluetooth Low Energy health device specification will not interoperate with any PHGs that do not have pre-coded knowledge of that new health device specification.

column14: The Device resource in FHIR has just undergone major changes. The DeviceComponent resource, used in a preliminary version of this IG has been merged into the Device and the DeviceComponent no longer exists. The productionSpecification element no longer exists as a backbone element but has been broken up into its concomitant parts. A new specializations field has been added. There is also a udiCarrier element which will support the new 20601 MDS Udi attribute. Though the changes in the Device related resources have been radical, the changes are much more suitable for PHDs.

column14: Extension for the PHG
column16:
The current text refers from Observation to PHG with an extension. Is this extension necessary? The PhdBaseObservation refers to the PHD, which could refers to the PHG as parent device. 
In the rare case that multiple PHGs can upload the same observations from one PHD, two PhdDevice resources could be created or the PhdDevice resource could be extended with multiple references to PHGs.
At the very least, the motivation for this extension needs to be included in this IG.
column17: The current text refers from Observation to PHG with an extension. Is this extension necessary?
